Federated Learning via Consensus Mechanism on Heterogeneous Data: A New Perspective on Convergence

ShuÂ Zheng â€ƒâ€ƒ TiandiÂ Ye â€ƒâ€ƒ XiangÂ Li 111 Corresponding author. Email: xiangli@ecnu.edu.cn.
â€ Â  Authors contributed equally. Order chosen alphabetically. â€ƒâ€ƒ MingÂ Gao East China Normal University
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) on heterogeneous data (non-IID data) has recently received great attention. Most existing methods focus on studying the convergence guarantees for the global objective. While these methods can guarantee the decrease of the global objective in each communication round, they fail to ensure risk decrease for each client. In this paper, to address the problem, we propose FedCOME, which introduces a consensus mechanism to enforce decreased risk for each client after each training round. In particular, we allow a slight adjustment to a clientâ€™s gradient on the server side, which generates an acute angle between the corrected gradient and the original ones of other clients. We theoretically show that the consensus mechanism can guarantee the convergence of the global objective. To generalize the consensus mechanism to the partial participation FL scenario, we devise a novel client sampling strategy to select the most representative clients for the global data distribution. Training on these selected clients with the consensus mechanism could empirically lead to risk decrease for clients that are not selected. Finally, we conduct extensive experiments on four benchmark datasets to show the superiority of FedCOMEÂ against other state-of-the-art methods in terms of effectiveness, efficiency and fairness. For reproducibility, we make our source code publicly available at: https://github.com/fedcome/fedcome.

\ecaisubmission

1 Introduction

Recent years have witnessed the great success of deep learning in a wide range of fields, such as computer visionÂ [41, 10], natural language processingÂ [6, 33] and speech recognitionÂ [34, 32]. Typically, deep learning relies on a tremendous amount of high-quality data, which is usually scattered over thousands or millions of edge devices, such as mobile phones and IoT sensors. With the increasing awareness of data privacy protection and the data regulations coming into force, it is illegal to collect clientsâ€™ data and perform model training in a centralized fashion. To address the problem, federated learning (FL) has emerged as a promising and powerful approach for model training from decentralized data without compromising clientsâ€™ data privacyÂ [13, 28, 4, 26, 30, 5].

Specifically, FL is a special distributed machine learning paradigm, with the goal of minimizing the average risk over the population, which proceeds in communication rounds between server and clients until convergence or reaching some termination criteria. In each round, the server first randomly selects a subset of clients. Then the selected clients download the latest model from the server and optimize it based on their private datasets. After that, clientsâ€™ local gradients (or model updates) are sent to the server after local training finishes and aggregated by the server to update the global model.

Recently, FL on heterogeneous data (i.e., non-identically distributed data) across all the clients has received great attention [42, 21, 18, 19, 14, 39, 1]. With the assumption of bounded data heterogeneity, most existing worksÂ [18, 19] focus on theoretically proving the convergence guarantees for the global objective. While these works can guarantee the decrease of the global objective in each communication round, they fail to ensure risk decrease for each client. Intuitively, a decrease in the risk of each client could further decrease the average risk over the whole population and gradually moves the global objective function to converge as training proceeds. With this perspective, in this paper, we study the convergence of the global objective function by proposing a consensus mechanism that ensures the decreased risk for all the clients in each iteration under the full client participation assumption. In particular, we allow a slight adjustment to a clientâ€™s gradient on the server-side, which generates an acute angle between the corrected gradient and the original ones of other clients. The consensus mechanism is theoretically proved to serve as a sufficient condition for the decreases of local risks for all the clients and further the decrease of the global objective over the whole population.

The consensus mechanism can only guarantee decreased risks for clients used in training. However, in the large-scale cross-device FL scenario, it is usual that only a subset of clients are available. To generalize the consensus mechanism to the partial client participation scenario, we design a sampling strategy to select the most representative clients for the global population. Specifically, we first quantify the similarity between clients by their gradients and then maintain a similarity table Sğ‘†S, in which the (i,j)ğ‘–ğ‘—(i,j)-th entry represents the similarity between the iğ‘–i-th and jğ‘—j-th clients. The sampling objective is to select a subset of clients ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} according to table Sğ‘†S, where the sum of similarities between any two clients in ğ’«ğ’«\mathcal{P} is minimized. After that, the consensus mechanism can be applied on these selected clients to guarantee their decreased risks, which can also lead to empirical decreases of risks for clients that are not selected.

Finally, based on the consensus mechanism and the sampling strategy, we develop a novel and easy-to-implement Federated learning framework via COnsensus MEchanism, namely, FedCOME. Different from most existing methods, FedCOMEÂ  studies the convergence of global objective in FL on heterogeneous data by guaranteeing the decrease of each clientâ€™s risk in each communication round, which further leads to the decrease of the global risk. In summary, this paper aims to shed light on the new direction for studying the data heterogeneity problem in FL and provide insightful reference for future research on the topic. Our main contributions in this paper are summarized as follows:

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet We propose a novel FL framework FedCOME, which provides a new perspective for studying the convergence of the global objective in FL on heterogeneous data.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet We introduce a consensus mechanism to ensure decreased risk for all the clients in each communication round. We theoretically prove that the consensus mechanism can guarantee the convergence of the global objective.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet We design an effective client sampling strategy to select most representative clients for the global data distribution, which can be used to generalize the consensus mechanism to the partial participation scenario.

âˆ™âˆ™\bullet We conduct extensive experiments on four benchmark FL datasets to demonstrate the superiority of FedCOMEÂ in terms of effectiveness, efficiency and fairness.

2 Related Work

2.1 Data Heterogeneity

In real-world scenarios, data is generally heterogeneous across clients, which poses great challenges to FL. To address the problem, existing works can be mainly categorized into two types.

To alleviate the discrepancy of data distributions among clients, the first line of approaches regularize local model training by adding various constraints to clientsâ€™ optimization objectivesÂ [18, 14, 1, 3, 31]. For example, FedProxÂ [18] adds a proximal term to regularize the distance between the global model and the local client model in parameter space. InÂ [14], the client drift problem is introduced and SCAFFOLD is proposed to address the problem by correcting local updates with control variates. FedDCÂ [9] utilizes an auxiliary local drift variable to track and bridge the gap between the parameters of the local and the global model. Further, FedDynÂ [1] points out the misalignment between the stationary points of the client models and that of the server model, and aligns them through dynamically updating the local regularizer. In a special non-IID setting where clients have imbalanced class distributions, FedRodÂ [3] leverages balanced risk to align clientsâ€™ objectives and improve the model performance.

Another line of methods handle data heterogeneity with sophisticated model aggregation on the serverÂ [12, 39, 38, 44, 25, 40]. The most naive aggregation scheme is the coordinate-based parameter averaging adopted by FedAvgÂ [28]. Further, WangÂ etÂ al.Â [38] point out the misalignment issue between clientsâ€™ models due to the permutation invariant property of neural networks, and they offer a matched averaging scheme to mitigate the issue. There also exist knowledge distillation techniques that are utilized to integrate clientsâ€™ knowledge into the global modelÂ [25, 44], which have been shown to be more effective than simple parameter averaging.

2.2 Continual Learning

There is an implicit connection between continual learning and federated learning. Continual learning is a concept of learning a series of tasks sequentially without forgetting previously learned knowledge, while federated learning is a special multi-task learning paradigm, where all tasks (clients) are learned in parallel. These two learning paradigms could suffer from the same challenge that the tasks negatively affect each other when their data distributions vary considerably, which exacerbates catastrophic forgettingÂ [8] in continual learning and slows down the model convergence in federated learning.

To solve the challenge, some continual learning methods have been proposedÂ [23, 15, 27]. For example, EWCÂ [15] adds a penalty term to the objective function to penalize the modification on parameters that are most informative for prior tasks. GEMÂ [27] allows positive knowledge transfer to past tasks through gradient projection. Meanwhile, these approaches have been extended to federated learning [37, 40, 7, 22]. For example, to alleviate local models drifting apart, FedCurvÂ [37] adapts EWCÂ [15] to federated learning, which uses the diagonal of the Fisher information matrix to protect the parameters that are important to all clients. Inspired by GEMÂ [27], a decentralized learning method CGAÂ [7] is developed, where the cross gradients (computed by neighbors) and local gradients are projected into an aggregated gradient. While our method utilizes the idea of continual learning, we focus on parallel training clients instead of sequential tasks.

2.3 Fairness

Another related research direction to our paper is fairnessÂ [20, 29, 40], which aims to derive a model that has comparable performances over all the clients. For example, AFLÂ [29] formulates FL as a min-max optimization problem, where the global model can be optimized for any target distribution formed by a mixture of client distributions. LiÂ etÂ al.Â [20] minimize a reweighted loss where the clients with worse performance are given higher relative weights. Further, FedFVÂ [40] identifies the conflicting gradients with large differences in magnitudes as a cause of unfairness, and proposes to mitigate the issue via gradient projection. Instead of targeting at fairness, our proposed method attempts to making all the clients benefit from federated training rather than achieve similar performance.

4 Methodology

In this section, we formulate our optimization objective and present our framework FedCOME.

4.1 Consensus Mechanism

Instead of directly analyzing the global objective, we propose a consensus mechanism to ensure risk decrease for each client in each communication round. Intuitively, if the risk of each client decreases, the average risk over the whole population will also decrease. As the training proceeds, the global model could converge. With this perspective, we formulate our optimization objective in the ttâ€‹hsubscriptğ‘¡ğ‘¡â„t_{th} round as:

minÎ¸t+1Fâ€‹(Î¸t)s.t.Fkâ€‹(Î¸t+1)â‰¤Fkâ€‹(Î¸t),âˆ€ukâˆˆU.\begin{split}&\min_{\theta^{t+1}}\quad F(\theta^{t})\\ &\operatorname{s.t.}\quad F_{k}(\theta^{t+1})\leq F_{k}(\theta^{t}),\forall u_{k}\in U.\end{split} (2)

In this way, we minimize the global objective while constraining that each client benefits from federated training. Next, we present our consensus mechanism to solve the constrained optimization problemÂ (2). For ease of description, we first define consensus on two clients.

Definition 1 (Consensus).

Given two clients uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} and ujsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—u_{j}, if their gradients gisubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–g_{i} and gjsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘—g_{j} satisfy giâ‹…gjâ‰¥0â‹…subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–subscriptğ‘”ğ‘—0g_{i}\cdot g_{j}\geq 0, we say that client uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} reaches a consensus with client ujsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—u_{j}.

Note that the consensus mechanism is employed on the server side, where clientsâ€™ gradients are allowed to be slightly modified to promote consensus among clients. Meanwhile, we have to restrain too much deviation of the modified client gradients from the original ones. For notation simplicity, we omit the round index tğ‘¡t and formulate the objective of the consensus mechanism as:

where g~isubscript~ğ‘”ğ‘–\tilde{g}_{i} is the modified gradient of client uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} and gjsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘—g_{j} is the original gradient of client ujsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—u_{j}. 4.2 Theoretical Analysis

We provide theoretical analysis in the setting of full participation, full batch size and only one local epoch update in each round, which is the same as FedSGD. It can be easily extended to multiple epochs and minibatch settings when the learning rate is small enough. First, we make a general assumption as inÂ [36, 24]:

For time complexity, FedCOME requires solving a quadratic programming (QP) problem of size Mğ‘€M, the number of selected clients per round. Solving the QP problem incurs ğ’ªâ€‹(M3.5)ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘€3.5\mathcal{O}(M^{3.5}) time complexity (worst-case),which is acceptable for a server with enough computing power due to M<<Nmuch-less-thanğ‘€ğ‘M<<N, the population size.

4.3 Client Sampling

In the previous section, we have shown that all the clientsâ€™ risks decrease after each round in the full participation setting. However, in practice, it is usual that only a subset of clients are available for training in each round. The consensus mechanism can only guarantee decreased risks for clients used in training. To generalize the consensus mechanism to unavailable clients, we design a novel sampling strategy, where the most representative clients for the global population are selected for training. Specifically, we maintain a similarity table SâˆˆRNÃ—Nğ‘†superscriptğ‘…ğ‘ğ‘S\in R^{N\times N} on the server such that Siâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘—S_{ij} represents the similarity between the iğ‘–i-th and jğ‘—j-th clients. And Siâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘—S_{ij} is initialized to 0. Based on Sğ‘†S, we can select a subset of clients ğ’«tsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡\mathcal{P}_{t} of size Mğ‘€M in the tğ‘¡t-th round, where the sum of similarities between any two clients in ğ’«tsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡\mathcal{P}_{t} is minimized. Formally, the objective is formulated as:

minğ’«tâ¡{Hâ€‹(ğ’«t):=âˆ‘ui,ujâˆˆğ’«tSiâ€‹j},subscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡assignğ»subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡subscriptsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘—\displaystyle\min_{\mathcal{P}_{t}}\left\{H(\mathcal{P}_{t}):=\sum_{u_{i},u_{j}\in\mathcal{P}_{t}}S_{ij}\right\}, (13)

which is a combinatorial optimization problem and can be solved by the simulated annealing method. Initially, we construct ğ’«t0superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡0\mathcal{P}_{t}^{0} by randomly selecting a subset of clients from Uğ‘ˆU. After that, in the (r+1ğ‘Ÿ1r+1)-th iteration, we construct ğ’«tr+1superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ1\mathcal{P}_{t}^{r+1} by randomly replacing a client in ğ’«trsuperscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{P}_{t}^{r} with a random client from U/ğ’«trğ‘ˆsuperscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘ŸU/\mathcal{P}_{t}^{r}. Note that ğ’«tr+1superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ1\mathcal{P}_{t}^{r+1} will be accepted with a probability minâ¡{1,expâ¡(âˆ’(Hâ€‹(ğ’«tr+1)âˆ’Hâ€‹(ğ’«tr))Ï„)}1ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ1ğ»superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿğœ\min\{1,\exp(\frac{-\left(H(\mathcal{P}_{t}^{r+1})-H(\mathcal{P}_{t}^{r})\right)}{\tau})\}, where Ï„ğœ\tau is the temperature parameter and decays with iterations; otherwise, we set ğ’«tr+1=ğ’«trsuperscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ1superscriptsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡ğ‘Ÿ\mathcal{P}_{t}^{r+1}=\mathcal{P}_{t}^{r}. To enhance the diversity of ğ’«tsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡\mathcal{P}_{t} and prevent the model from easily trapping into the local minimum, we further introduce the exploitation-exploration strategy. When constructing ğ’«tsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡\mathcal{P}_{t}, Î¼â€‹Mğœ‡ğ‘€\mu M clients are derived by the simulated annealing method while others are selected randomly. Here, Î¼ğœ‡\mu is a pre-defined percentage.

After ğ’«tsubscriptğ’«ğ‘¡\mathcal{P}_{t} is derived, for any two clients ui,ujâˆˆğ’«tsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—subscriptğ’«ğ‘¡u_{i},u_{j}\in\mathcal{P}_{t}, we compute their gradient cosine similarity, given by:

Qiâ€‹j=âŸ¨gi,gjâŸ©â€–giâ€–â€‹â€–gjâ€–.subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘”ğ‘–subscriptğ‘”ğ‘—normsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘–normsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘—Q_{ij}=\frac{\left\langle g_{i},g_{j}\right\rangle}{\|g_{i}\|\|g_{j}\|}. (14)

Then we update Siâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘—S_{ij} by

Siâ€‹jâ†Î±â€‹Siâ€‹j+(1âˆ’Î±)â€‹Qiâ€‹j,â†subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ›¼subscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ›¼subscriptğ‘„ğ‘–ğ‘—S_{ij}\leftarrow\alpha S_{ij}+(1-\alpha)Q_{ij}, (15)

where Î±ğ›¼\alpha is a balancing coefficient. In this way, we will select clients whose data distributions are heterogeneous. For clients uisubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘–u_{i} and ujsubscriptğ‘¢ğ‘—u_{j} that have IID data distributions, they are more likely to generate similar gradients and large Siâ€‹jsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘–ğ‘—S_{ij} value. Therefore, only one of them will be selected. Note that our client sampling strategy covers heterogeneous data of clients as much as possible. When one client is selected, others that are not selected but with IID data distributions can also benefit from the consensus mechanism. This further boosts the generalizablity of the consensus mechanism. Finally, we combine client sampling and consensus mechanism, and summarize the pseudocodes of FedCOMEÂ in AlgorithmÂ 2 of the supplementary materials. The time complexity of our proposed client sampling strategy is ğ’ªâ€‹(Ï„âˆ—N)ğ’ªğœğ‘\mathcal{O}(\tau*N), where Ï„ğœ\tau is the stopping-iterations and Ï„=600ğœ600\tau=600 in our experiments.

4.4 Discussion

We next summarize the major difference between FedCOMEÂ and other two competitors including SCAFFOLD and FedFV from the perspective of consensus.

SCAFFOLD uses control variate to mitigate the discrepancy between clientsâ€™ gradients, which can be considered as a soft correction for promoting the consensus across clients. In contrast, FedCOME imposes a hard correction on clientsâ€™ model updates.

FedFV and FedCOMEÂ achieve the consensus across clients through iterative gradient projection and quadratic programming, respectively. The former is more likely to lose the original gradients information, while the latter only allows slight modification on client gradients.

Further, FedCOMEÂ does not introduce additional communication cost and allows clients to be stateless, which broadens its applicability in cross-device FL settings.

5 Experiments

In this section, we conduct extensive experiments to evaluate the effectiveness of FedCOME. Due to the space limitation, we provide details of datasets and baselines in the supplementary materials.

5.1 Datasets and Baselines

We use four FL benchmark datasets, including MNISTÂ [17], FEMNISTÂ [2], CIFAR-10Â [16] and CIFAR-100Â [16]. Further, we consider 6 other methods as baselines, including FedAvgÂ [28], FedProxÂ [18], SCAFFOLDÂ [14], FedDynÂ [1], FedFVÂ [40] and FedDCÂ [9]. In particular, FedProx, SCAFFOLD, FedDyn and FedDC are specially designed for addressing data heterogeneity, while FedFV deals with fairness across clients.

5.2 Implementation details

We implement FedCOMEÂ using PyTorch and train it by SGD optimizer. In our experiments, the balancing coefficient Î±ğ›¼\alpha in Eq.Â 15 and the percentage Î¼ğœ‡\mu are set to 0.5 and 0.7, respectively. For all the methods, we set the local minibatch size to 50, weight decay to 1e-3 and learning rate to 0.05 with a learning rate decay of 0.998 per round. Further, clients are set to perform local optimization for five epochs on CIFAR-100 and one epoch on other datasets. For all the baselines, we perform grid search to fine-tune their hyper-parameters, whose search space is summarized in TableÂ 5 of Appendix. We implement FedFV and FedDC with the official codes released by their authors and use the codes released byÂ [9] for other baselines. For each dataset, we adopt the same neural network model for all the methods. Specifically, we adopt a fully connected network with one hidden layer of 64 units on MNIST. Similar as inÂ [28], for CIFAR10, CIFAR-100 and FEMNIST, we use a ConvNetÂ [17] that contains 2 convolutional layers and 2 fully connected layers. All the experiments are run on one Tesla V100 GPU.

5.3 Results in Full Participation

We next force all the clients to participate in each round of training and show the classification results in tableÂ 1. We evaluate the performance of all the methods w.r.t. the weighted average accuracy, where the weights are proportional to the client sample sizes. The accuracy is reported with mean and standard deviation over three random runs. From the table, we see that FedCOMEÂ beats other competitors on MNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100. While FedCOMEÂ is not the winner on FEMNIST, it can still achieve comparable performance with the best result. These observations show the effectiveness of our method FedCOME, which optimizes the global objective while ensuring decreased risks for all the clients after each iteration.

To further study model efficiency, we plot the convergence curves of all the methods on all the datasets in FigureÂ 1. From the figure, we see that FedCOME, FedDC and FedDyn are among the best three in terms of convergence speed. While FedDC performs very well on MNIST and FEMNIST datasets, it converges very slow on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100, which shows its instability. For FedCOMEÂ and FedDyn, they have comparable convergence speeds. For example, both of them outperform other methods by a large margin on CIFAR-10 and CIFAR-100. However, our method FedCOMEÂ can converge to higher accuracy values, which are also clarified in TableÂ 1. These results show that our method FedCOMEÂ is both effective and efficient.

5.4 Effect of Data Heterogeneity

To examine the robustness of FedCOMEÂ against varying degrees of data heterogeneity, we further conduct experiments on CIFAR-10 to simulate different degrees of heterogeneity. We set the number of classes Câˆˆ{2,3,4}ğ¶234C\in\{2,3,4\} that each client has at most. The smaller Cğ¶C is, the fewer data overlap between clients and the stronger data heterogeneity among clients. Experimental results are shown in TableÂ 2. From the table, we see that both FedCOMEÂ and FedDyn outperform other methods when meeting data heterogeneity. Compared with FedDyn, FedCOMEÂ performs better as data heterogeneity increases. This shows the advantage of FedCOMEÂ in dealing with data heterogeneity.

5.5 Fairness

FedCOMEÂ optimizes the global objective subject to decreased risks for all the clients after each communication round. In other words, all the clients can benefit from the federated training, which motivates further study on fairness. Specifically, we compare FedCOMEÂ with FedFV, which is specially designed for handling fairness in FL. We plot the test accuracy distribution over the clients on FEMNIST and CIFAR-10 in FigureÂ 4. From the figure, it is clear that FedCOMEÂ exhibits sharper distributions than FedFV on both datasets, which shows that FedCOMEÂ can lead to better fairness among clients.

5.6 Results in Partial Participation

To verify the effectiveness of our method in the partial participation FL scenario, we run all the methods on CIFAR-10 with the same settings as in the full participation scenario. We vary the participation ratio per round from {10%,20%,30%,40%}percent10percent20percent30percent40\{10\%,20\%,30\%,40\%\}. For each method, we run two variants: one with our proposed client sampling strategy (shown in regular fonts) and the other with random sampling (shown in small fonts). Experimental results are shown in TableÂ 3. From the table, we observe that:

  • â€¢

    FedCOMEÂ beats other competitors across all the participation ratios with our proposed sampling strategy. With random sampling, FedCOMEÂ performs the best when the participation ratio is high (30% and 40%). When the ratio is small (10% and 20%), FedDyn is the winner because it can utilize the gradients of previously selected clients. Despite this, FedCOMEÂ can achieve comparable performance with FedDyn. These results show the superiority of FedCOMEÂ in handling data heterogeneity.

  • â€¢

    All the methods with our proposed client sampling strategy generally perform better than using random sampling, which demonstrates the effectiveness of our client sampling strategy.

  • â€¢

    Our proposed sampling strategy can lead to large gain against random sampling when participation ratio is small. For example, when only 10% of clients participate in training in each round, FedCOMEÂ with our client sampling strategy improves that with random sampling by 2.77%. This shows that our sampling strategy can select more representative clients for the global data distribution.

5.7 Client Loss Study

We end this section with an additional study on CIFAR-10 to show the loss of each client derived by FedCOMEÂ after each training round in both full and partial participation settings. We set learning rate to 0.01 and each client performs local optimization for one epoch with full batch size. In the partial participation experiment, we set the participation ratio to 20%. FigureÂ 2 shows each clientâ€™s loss curve in the full participation setting. From the figure, we see that each clientâ€™s loss keeps decreasing with training epoches. This can be attributed to our consensus mechanism. Further, in the partial participation setting, Fig.Â 3 shows that the loss curves of all the clients (including those clients not selected) derived by FedCOMEÂ with our proposed sampling strategy keep decreasing while that with random sampling fluctuate frequently. This further shows the effectiveness of our proposed sampling strategy.

5.8 Sensitivity analysis of hyper-parameters

We perform the hyper-parameter sensitivity study and show the results of FedCOME on CIFAR-10 dataset with a 20% participation ratio. We present the experiment results in TableÂ 4. From the table, we see that our method can achieve stable performance when Î±âˆˆ{0.5,0.7,0.9}ğ›¼0.50.70.9\alpha\in\{0.5,0.7,0.9\} and Î¼âˆˆ{0.5,0.7,0.9}ğœ‡0.50.70.9\mu\in\{0.5,0.7,0.9\}. So we set Î±=0.5ğ›¼0.5\alpha=0.5 and Î¼=0.7ğœ‡0.7\mu=0.7.

6 Conclusion

In this paper, we studied data heterogeneity in FL and proposed FedCOMEÂ that provides a new perspective on the convergence of the global objective. We presented a consensus mechanism to guarantee decreased risk for each client after each communication round. Based on the consensus mechanism, we theoretically proved the decrease of the global risk over the whole population. To further generalize the consensus mechanism to partial participation FL scenario, we devised a novel client sampling strategy. We conducted extensive experiments on 4 benchmark datasets to show the effectiveness and efficiency of FedCOME. Also, we showed the advantage of FedCOMEÂ in ensuring fairness among clients.

Ethical Statement

Same as FedAvgÂ [28] and its variants like SCAFFOLDÂ [14], FedCOMEÂ also has a risk of information leakage due to the transmission of local gradients or model updates, but it can be easily mitigated with differential privacy or other defense techniques, such as gradient clippingÂ [43].

Appendix A Datasets

We use four FL benchmark datasets, including MNISTÂ [17], FEMNISTÂ [2], CIFAR-10Â [16] and CIFAR-100Â [16]. Details on these datasets are summarized in TableÂ 6.

  • â€¢

    MNIST is a handwritten digit recognition dataset. FollowingÂ [28], we partition the dataset into 100 clients evenly, each of which has only 2 out of 10 classes.

  • â€¢

    FEMNIST is a more complex version of MNIST. It contains 62-class handwritten digits and letters. This dataset is partitioned based on the writer of digit/letter, which is inherently heterogeneous.

  • â€¢

    CIFAR-10 is a 10-class image classification dataset. Similar as MNIST, we construct a federated dataset composed of 100 clients, each of which has only two classes.

  • â€¢

    CIFAR-100 is a 100-class image classification dataset. We split it into 20 subsets by superclass labels, where each subset is evenly distributed into 5 clients. There are 100 clients in total and data heterogeneity exists between clients from different subsets.

Appendix B Baselines

We consider 6 other methods as baselines, whose details are given as follows. In particular, FedProx, SCAFFOLD, FedDyn and FedDC are specially designed for addressing data heterogeneity, while FedFV deals with fairness across clients.

  • â€¢

    FedAvgÂ [28] is the vanilla FL method that aggregates model updates weighted by their sample sizes.

  • â€¢

    FedProxÂ [18] adds a proximal item to each clientâ€™s local optimization objective to prevent local model from diverging from global model.

  • â€¢

    SCAFFOLDÂ [14] regularizes the local training with estimated control variates to alleviate client-drift caused by heterogeneity.

  • â€¢

    FedDynÂ [1] updates the local regularizer dynamically to ensure the minima of the local empirical loss conforms with that of the global empirical risk.

  • â€¢

    FedFVÂ [40] performs gradient projection between clientsâ€™ conflicting gradients to address the unfairness issue.

  • â€¢

    FedDCÂ [9] utilizes an auxiliary local drift variable to track and bridge the gap between the parameters of the local and the global model.
